He ran the numbers and came up with a fair value of just $205 per share .  Tesla has always had its own playbook, and some say a big part of its valuation is the Musk premium . With slowing growth and rising competition, this could be a moment for investors to take a closer look at the actual numbers .

We recently published a list of Jim Cramer’s 9 Failed Predictions from 12 months ago . In this article, we are going to take a look at where Tesla, Inc. (NASDAQ:TSLA) stands against other stocks that Cramer discussed .  Cramer discussed 9 stocks that were discussed by Jim Cramer during Mad Money episodes that aired on the 7thand 8thof May 2024 . We calculated their performance for the past 12 months, until May 7th, 2025, market close . We have also included the hedge fund sentiment for the stocks, which we sourced from Insider Monkey’s Q4 2024 database of over 900 hedge funds .  Tesla, Inc. has returned 373.4% since May 2014, beating its benchmark by 218 percentage points . Cramer got this one wrong as Tesla surged 55.35% despite the issues he highlighted . Markets were cheering the latest US-China trade deal, after which the two countries will significantly reduce tariffs on each other’s imports for 90 days . The deal practically negates all bear cases modeled by Wall Street analysts based on the impact of tariffs . With each stock we have mentioned the latest hedge fund sentiment .  Steve Westley from The Westley Group said in a latest program onSchwab Network that Tesla, Inc. (NASDAQ:TSLA) may not have hit the rock bottom yet . Westley pointed out the key problems visible in the company’s Q1 report . Tesla sales fell about 12% year over year in 2024, causing its market share to drop .  Tesla delivered just 1,429 new cars in Germany in February, down 76% from the same month last year . In contrast, battery-electric vehicle (BEV) registrations surged 30.8% during the month . Californians purchased more than 2 million electric cars during the year .  TSLA trades at less than 5 times its earnings per year . That's less than five times the price of a stock that trades at under 5 times earnings .

The S&P 500 (^GSPC) soared nearly 3.3% to its highest level since March 3 . The Dow Jones Industrial Average (^DJI) gained 2.8%, or more than 1,100 points . The tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite (^IXIC) led gains, rocketing up 4.3%.  The S&P 500 (^GSPC) soared 3.3%, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average (^DJI) gained 2.3% on Monday . April’sConsumer Price Index (CPI) report is due Tuesday, followed by retail sales and the Producer Price Index on Thursday .  Bitcoin (BTC-USD) fell more than 2% on Monday to hover below $102,000 per token . The world's largest cryptocurrency touched a session high north of $105,000 before declining . Bitcoin is up more than 8% year-to-date .  Comments of tariffs in the industrials sector climbed to 61 from 10 during the post-election period . Some companies have pulled their outlook during this past earnings season, citing uncertainty stemming from tariffs . President Trump excluded auto imports from the tariff pause his administration reached with China on Monday .  West Texas Intermediate (CL=F) futures rallied over 2% to hover near $62.50 per barrel . Brent crude (BZ=F), the international benchmark, also rebounded to trade above $65 . Monday's oil price rally was exacerbated by a likely short position covering after talks between the US and China resulted in a 90-day pause on tariffs .  President Trump promised to cut the cost of pharmaceutical drugs in the US on Monday via an executive order . "We're getting them down 67%, 80%, 90%," Trump said . The president said the US has the highest prices in the world, as pharmaceutical companies make most of their profits .  Gold futures tumbled 3% as investors jumped into equities, selling off the safe-haven asset . Trump said he plans to speak with China's President Xi Jinping, "maybe at the end of the week" The precious metal is up roughly 24% year to date after a massive run-up .  Big Tech stocks continue to rally premarket on temporary reprieve in US and China tariffs . Amazon (AMZN) and Tesla (TSLA) lead the morning's "Magnificent Seven" gains . The Nasdaq Composite (IXIC) surged over 3%, while the S&P 500 (GSPC) soared 3%. The Dow Jones Industrial Average (^DJI) jumped more than 2.4%, or over 1,000 points .  US tech stocks rallied across the board on news of a US-China trade deescalation . Amazon (AMZN) spiked 7.6% on Monday morning . Apple (AAPL) surged 6.2%, Meta (META) added 5.5%, and Alphabet (GOOG,GOOGL) advanced 2.4% .  S&P 500 futures climbed 3%, while Dow Jones Industrial Average futures gained 2.4%, or around 1,000 points . Nasdaq 100 (NQ=F) led gains, soaring 3.8% . Meanwhile, the US dollar (DX-Y.NYB) gained 1.4% and Bitcoin (BTC-USD) declined slightly, down 0.25% . Gold (GC) tumbled 3.6% to trade around $3,220 per ounce .  Crude oil, copper (HG=F) and crop futures rose, but gold prices sank after the US and China said they had agreed to a mutual reduction in tariffs . Brent crude rose 2.4% to trade above $65 a barrel, WTI crude jumped 2.6% to almost $63 a barrel .  Both sides described recent US-China trade negotiations as showing “substantial progress” Bloomberg reports: Read more here. looked for concrete outcomes from recent U.S.-China trade talks .

Technological advances are always at the heart of disruption on Wall Street . However, it will mean a slow, painful death for companies who fail to adapt and evolve . The rewards are substantial for companies that respond to market changes and debut new technologies .  Robotaxis promise to reduce human error and distraction, reducing the number of accidents . By eliminating the need for human drivers, ride-hailing operators can become far more profitable . Robotaxis don’t need to take breaks like humans (outside of recharging), they can run nearly 24/7 .  Next month, Tesla will start to roll out its robotaxi to customers through its in-house built mobile application . Musk has said several times over the past few years that he is “betting the company” on autonomous vehicle technology .  While Waymo currently holds a significant lead, Tesla’s impending entry (with game-changing cost advantage) injects uncertainty into the future landscape of autonomous transportation . It means the robotaxi wars may just be starting . Tesla's lower cost could allow it to catch up in scale and enjoy jucier profit margins .  Investment Research is based in New York City, New York, and London, USA . It is based on a $1.2 billion investment in the U.S. investment market .

Tesla (NASDAQ:TSLA)rockets past a $1 trillion market capas easing U.S. trade tensions and a risk-on rally lift shares more than 5% in regular trade . The stock had been under pressure in recent months as steep duties on Chinese-sourced components threatened to derail production economics for Tesla's Cybercab sedan and Semi truck .  Hitting the $1 trillion mark underscores Tesla's resilience amid trade volatility and signals renewed investor confidence in its EV growth trajectory . Tesla's presence at the Saudi-U.S. investment forum in Riyadh highlights its global expansion push .

Mercedes-Benz CEO Ola Källenius says company has no plans to raise prices to offset tariffs from the Trump administration . He says the company will not restore the financial outlook it withdrew several weeks ago amid the uncertainty .  More than half of the 374,000 vehicles Mercedes-Benz sold in the US last year were imported . About 13% of German car exports go to the United States, more than to any other country . Mercedes will start producing its top-selling GLC SUV at its plant in Alabama .  Mercedes-Benz sales declined 4% in the first quarter . Sales in North America advanced 1%, a 7% decline in Europe and a 10% decrease in China overshadowed the gain . Källenius: "No" guidance will be restored as more clarity on tariffs has been received .

Tesla (NASDAQ:TSLA) shares jumped more than6% at Monday's open, pushing the company's market value past the $1 trillionmark . The broader market rallied on hopes of eased U.S. trade frictions . The S&P 500 climbed about 2.5% as investors cheered a temporary tariff reduction, which also lifted semiconductors and automakers .  Riyadh to showcase its leading electric-vehicle range and tap into Saudi Arabia's push for clean energy . Saudi Arabia to showcase leading electric vehicle range .

Auto stocks, led by Tesla, charged higher as the US and China reached a temporary trade reprieve . The auto sector was excluded from the deal, but optimism remains . Broader tariffs on foreign imports of autos and auto parts still apply to China .  Auto sector tariffs are taking a hatchet to automaker profits . GM said its full-year EBITcould take a $4 billion to $5 billion hit from tariffs . Toyota said tariffs would shave $1.3 billion in operating profits just from April and May alone .  GM imports the Buick Envision from the mainland, and Ford imports the Lincoln Nautilus from there . While the impact of tariffs on those models is limited, the broader 25% tariffs on auto parts are of most concern to the automakers .

U.S. auto safety investigators ask Tesla to answer questions on its plans to launch robotaxi service in Austin, Texas, in June . NHTSA says it has been investigating Tesla full self-driving collisions in reduced roadway visibility conditions since October . Tesla did not immediately respond to a request for comment .  NHTSA says it wants to know how many vehicles will be used as robotaxis . It also asks Tesla to describe how it intends to ensure safety of robotaxi operations in reduced roadway visibility conditions such as sun glare, fog, airborne dust, rain or snow .  Tesla recalled more than 2 million U.S. vehicles to install safeguards in its Autopilot advanced driver-assistance system . NHTSA is still probing whether that recall is adequate to address concerns drivers are not paying attention . At least two fatal accidents involving Tesla's full self-driving technology have occurred .

Tesla's Full Self-Driving (FSD) software still requires driver oversight . The company aims to release an unsupervised version of the software this year .  Based on the one year price targets offered by 44 analysts, the average target price for Tesla Inc is $282.45 . The average target implies a downside of -5.30% from the current price of $298.26 .

Tesla was an outperformer in the "Magnificent Seven" this morning . Over the weekend, officials from the U.S. and China agreed to a 90-day pause on elevated tariffs against one another . The Dow Jones Industrial Averagerocketed over 1,000 points, while the Nasdaq Compositerose roughly 3.7% .  Tesla was one of the stronger performers in the "Magnificent Seven" this morning . This is likely due to the fact that China plays a critical role in its business . The Shanghai factory in recent years has built more than half of Tesla's vehicles . US-China tariff standstill may mean the "Magnificent Seven" trade does anything but stay in place . The US and China agreed on Monday to reduce "reciprocal" tariffs on goods from China to 10% from 125% . The Roundhill Magnificent Seven ETF (MAGS) ripped 6% in premarket trading .  Traders use the Roundhill Magnificent Seven ETF as a proxy for the Mag 7, as its top holdings are the seven stocks . China will cut its retaliatory tariffs on US goods to 10% from 125% . The Mag 7 trade was climbing back into top form after a challenging stretch this year .  Goldman Sachs data shows Mag 7 companies delivered 28% average earnings growth in the first quarter . The 493 other stocks in the S&P 500 delivered only 9% growth . Some pros continue to advise caution before going all in again on the Mag 7 .  The latest episode of "Opening Bid" will feature the biggest names in business and markets on Opening Bid . Watch the full episode on our video hub at 10 a.m. ET .

Amazon (AMZN) and Meta (META) led the "Magnificent Seven" Big Tech stock surge Monday afternoon after the US and China announced a temporary trade war truce . Amazon shares rose 8.1%, while Meta spiked 7.9% . Tesla stock (TSLA) jumped 6.8%, pushing its market capitalization past $1 trillion . Apple (AAPL) shares rose 6.3% and Nvidia (NVDA) stock jumped 5.4% .  Some 90% of Apple iPhones are made in China . Chinese advertisers account for 14% of total spending on Amazon advertising in 2024, analysts say . Some 30% of the value of goods sold on Amazon comes from China .  Seven firms have had a rocky month after Trump’s April 2 “reciprocal tariff” plan was announced . Trump enacted a 10% tariff on all global imports on April 5 . At the same time, the US government placed export bans on Nvidia's H20 chips for China .  Laura Bratton shares her thoughts on the stock market . Follow her on Twitter @laurabratton and @YahooFinance .

Matthew LaBrotsaid he lost his "dream job" when he demanded Musk cede the reins . Tesla is poised to reclaim its spot in the trillion-dollar club of global megacaps on Monday .  LaBrot blamed his termination on calling for Musk to step down . He argued losing his "dream job" after nearly six years at the company was a price he was willing to pay .  The site argues Musk himself is to blame for plunging sales of Tesla cars . JPMorgan argued the brand damage wasunlike anything it had ever seen in the auto industry .  Shares in the company are now set to open 7.5% higher at $320 on news that a tariff pause with China has been reached . Even its stock chart looks promising, with the price finally breaking above its 200-day moving average .  Musk risks tearing up this social contract with those in his workforce that sought to make a difference in the climate crisis . LaBrot argues Musk has thrown his dedicated employees under the bus by implying they were the ones to have mismanaged the company in his absence .

U.S. and China agree on a trade deal that would temporarily lower tariffs between the two countries . Tesla (TSLA), Nvidia (NVDA), and other tech stocks are surging in premarket trading on the agreement . Pharmaceutical stocks are falling after President Donald Trump wrote he plans to reduce prescription drug prices . Bitcoin (BTCUSD) is little changed at around $104,000, while yields on the 10-year Treasury note are rising above 4.45%.  U.S. and China agree to slash tariffs on each other's imports for 90 days . Deal comes after tit-for-tat tariff hikes between the countries created volatile market movements . Shares of chipmakers AMD, Broadcom, and Nvidia are up 7%, 6%, and 5%, respectively .  Several pharmaceutical stocks are moving lower in premarket trading after President Trump said he would sign an executive order to reduce drug costs by 30% to 80% . Automaker stocks are also moving higher following the U.S. trade deal with China after previous tariff announcements on vehicle imports had caused share prices to drop . Shares of Stellantis (STLA) are jumping 7% in pre-market trading .  U.S. tariffs on all auto imports are set to be imposed by the U.N. State of the State of India is expected to impose a tariff on all car imports .

The Cybertruck range extender was designed to boost the vehicle's driving range . Tesla cited low demand and impracticality . The battery pack would have occupied 30% of the truck bed .  The decision marks another retreat from Tesla's original Cybertruck roadmap, which has faced pricing hikes and delivery delays since its 2023 production debut . Investors will be watching whether the company's future offerings, like robotaxi platform, gain more traction .

Shares in electric vehicle maker Tesla (TSLA) have climbed back to their highest point since February . The US and China have agreed to lower their tariffs on each other's imports by 115% for 90 days . Optimism around the latest developments have helped drive Tesla shares higher .  Alibaba is due to report its full-year results on Thursday . Analysts have forecast revenue growth of 6.2% year-on-year for 2025 . Alibaba has made notable progress in expanding its emerging AI and cloud infrastructure division .  Eli Lilly's drug Zepbound had shown "superior weight loss" over Novo Nordisk's Wegovy, Eli Lilly says . The drug is a dual GIP and GLP-1 receptor agonist at 10mg and 15mg . The main question now is whether momentum can be sustained in the next quarter and over the coming year .  Wegovy is the only GLP-1 obesity medication approved to prevent major cardiovascular events such as cardiovascular death, heart attack, and stroke . The drop in Novo Nordisk (NOVO-B.CO) shares came after president Trump vowed to cut US drug prices .  FTSE-listed drugmakers AstraZeneca and GSK were down 4% and 2.4% on Monday morning . Miner Glencore (GLEN.L) was the biggest riser on the FTTE 100, with its shares up 6.7% . Trump said prescription drug and pharmaceutical prices would be reduced by 30% to 80% .  The FTSE was led higher as the China trade de-escalation story boosted sentiment about the global economy, Chinese economy, metals and miners . "This is buying time for a more comprehensive deal – allows for time for the process and ‘mechanism’ in the words of Treasury secretary Bessent to take place . Fellow FTSe-listed miners Anglo American and Antofagasta jumped more than 6% on the news .

Google-owner Alphabet is exploring the option of allowing personal ownership of robotaxis . AI application demand continues to be booming . Waymo could partner with automotive original automotive original Tesla .  Pichai: "There is future optionality around personal ownership as well" CEO Elon Musk believes Tesla will have unsupervised full-service driving on personally owned cars by the end of the year . Waymo's consideration of licensing to automakers is in step with Tesla's plans .  Tesla is a speculative growth stock, and it's priced as such . Elon Musk says Waymo's cars are very expensive, made in low volume . Tesla is introducing its robotaxi concept, which has already been adopted, with a business model that its competitor just said it's .  There have been fears of a slowdown in spending on data centers and other AI-related activities . Nvidia provides graphics processing units (GPUs) that are essential in data centers . Data centers are needed to support the growth in AIapplication use .  Nvidia confirmed that it was still on track to make $75 billion in capital investments this year . Microsoft and Alphabet own two of the biggest data center hyperscalers in the market . The FTSE 100 (^FTSE) and European indices climbed on Monday . London's premier index was 0.6% higher by the closing bell . US stocks surged at the opening bell as details of a temporary trade deal with China came into focus .  The Dow Jones Industrial Average (^DJI) surged 2.3%, or around 1,000 points . The tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite (^IXIC) led gains, rocketing up 3.5% . Investors jumped into shares of Big Tech megacaps bruised by trade war worries .  UK companies are increasingly targeting high-potential markets outside the EU . Ireland and Italy have fallen out of the top ten export destinations for the first time since 2022 . India is also back in focus following the signing of a new UK-India trade agreement .  Gold futures were down by 3.5% to $3,226.30 per ounce, while the spot gold price lost 2.8% . The drop follows constructive trade discussions over the weekend that market participants interpreted as a potential turning point in strained relations between the world’s two largest economies .  Gold dips amid risk-on mood sparked by the US-China trade agreement that dulls demand for safe havens . The substantial rollback in duties, coupled with growing optimism about further trade deals with other partners, opens the door for a deeper pullback in gold prices . However, relief may prove short-lived as trade uncertainty is likely to persist .  The drop in Novo Nordisk (NOVO-B.CO) shares, as well as other pharmaceuticals stocks, came after president Trump vowed to cut US drug prices . Trump said that he would be signing "one of the most consequential Executive Orders" in US history on Monday .  A handful of miners and investment firms are topping London's premier index, which is up 0.5% as of 10.15am . Shares in FTSE-listed drugmakers AstraZeneca and GSK were down 4% and 2.4% respectively . Swiss company Roche (ROG.SW) fell nearly 3% and French company Sanofi dipped 1.6% .  The US dollar index (DX-Y.NYB) was up 1% to $101.32 . The gains were driven by a weekend announcement from the United States that it had reached a preliminary trade deal with China . Both sides said on Monday they would suspend 24% of additional ad valorem tariffs on goods from the other country for 90 days .  Expectations of tighter monetary conditions ahead pushed the greenback to a one-month high . The rate that UK businesses are laying people off gained pace in April . Employer confidence levels at an all-time low following the legislated increase in National Insurance payments and rise in the national living wage .  Dow Jones Industrial Average (YM=F) futures rose by over 480 points, or 1.2%, on Monday . Nasdaq 100 futures led gains with a 2.2% jump . The market-friendly momentum followed a weekend of high-level trade talks in Switzerland . The rally comes after a downbeat week for stocks .  Market watchers will have one eye on developments in president Donald Trump's trade negotiations as well as movements towards peace in the Russia-Ukraine war .

The end of the earnings season is always a good time to take a step back and see who shined . As a group, revenues beat analysts’ consensus estimates by 3.8% .  General Motors (NYSE:GM) reported revenues of $44.02 billion, up 2.3% year on year . This print exceeded analysts’ expectations by 2.7% . Rivian (NASDAQ:RIVN) reported revenue of $1.24 billion . The manufacturer of Amazon’s delivery trucks, Rivian designs, manufactures, and sells electric vehicles .  Rivian pulled off the biggest analyst estimates beat among its peers . The market seems happy with the results as the stock is up 5.5% since reporting . Tesla delivered fewer vehicles than forecasted, its revenue in all three segments missed, and its EPS fell short of Wall Street’s estimates .  Lucid Group (NASDAQ:LCID) reported revenues of $235 million, up 36.1% year on year . Lucid achieved the fastest revenue growth among its peers . The stock is up 8.2% since reporting and currently trades at $2.51 .  Winnebago reported revenues of $620.2 million, down 11.9% year on year . This result beat analysts’ expectations by 0.6% . The stock is down 2.1% since reporting and currently trades at $34.02 .  These companies are poised for growth regardless of the political or macroeconomic climate . Tesla (TSLA) shares come into the week trading at their highest levels in more than two months . The stock confirmed a triple bottom pattern on Friday after breaking out above the formation's neckline and closing above the 200-day moving average . Investors should watch crucial overhead areas on Tesla's chart around $360 and $430 .  Tesla shares have recovered about 40% from last month’s low . However, the stock is still down 26% since the start of the year through Friday's close . Trade news will likely set the tone this week also after U.S.-China trade talks held over the weekend .  Tesla shares gained nearly 5% on Friday to around $298, the highest closing level since Feb. 25 . Further buying this week could see bulls drive a move up to the $360 area . Buying above this area may see a rally toward $430 .  Investors may seek buying opportunities in this region near the three prominent troughs that mark the triple bottom’s low . Tesla shares may revisit lower support at the $225 level .
